briefdescription.para: Returns a string formed by a printf()-like specification.

detaileddescription.para: The function is safe only to the extent that the arguments match the formatting string. In particular, be careful to pass strings themselves into TfStringPrintf() as in the above example (i.e. caller.c_str() as opposed to just passing caller).

simplesect.para: TfStringPrintf() is just a wrapper for ArchStringPrintf().

briefdescription.para: Returns a string formed by a printf()-like specification.

detaileddescription.para: TfVStringPrintf() is equivalent to TfStringPrintf() except that it is called with a va_list instead of a variable number of arguments. TfVStringPrintf() does not call the va_end macro. Consequently, the value of ap is undefined after the call. A functions that calls TfVStringPrintf() should call va_end(ap) itself afterwards.

simplesect.para: TfVStringPrintf() is just a wrapper for ArchVStringPrintf().

briefdescription.para: Bloat-avoidance version of TfVStringPrintf()
Safely create a std::string from a (possibly NULL) char*.

detaileddescription.para: If ptr is NULL, the empty string is safely returned.

briefdescription.para: Returns the given integer as a string.
Converts text string to double.

detaileddescription.para: This method converts strings to floating point numbers. It is similar to libc's atof(), but performs the conversion much more quickly.

It expects somewhat valid input: it will continue parsing the input until it hits an unrecognized character, as described by the regexp below, and at that point will return the results up to that point.

It will not check to see if there is any input at all, or whitespace after the digits. Ie: TfStringToDouble("") == 0.0 TfStringToDouble("blah") == 0.0 TfStringToDouble("-") == -0.0 TfStringToDouble("1.2foo") == 1.2

simplesect.para: TfStringToDouble is a wrapper around the extern-c TfStringToDouble

detaileddescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Convert a sequence of digits in txt to a long int value.

detaileddescription.para: Caller is responsible for ensuring that txt has content matching:
If the digit sequence's value is out of range, set *outOfRange to true (if outOfRange is not NULL) and return either std::numeric_limits<long>::min() or max(), whichever is closest to the true value.
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Convert a sequence of digits in txt to an unsigned long value.

detaileddescription.para: Caller is responsible for ensuring that txt has content matching:
If the digit sequence's value is out of range, set *outOfRange to true (if outOfRange is not NULL) and return std::numeric_limits<unsigned long>="">::max().
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Convert a sequence of digits in txt to an int64_t value.

detaileddescription.para: Caller must ensure that txt has content matching:

If the digit sequence's value is out of range, set *outOfRange to true (if outOfRange is not NULL) and return either std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::min() or max(), whichever is closest to the true value.
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Convert a sequence of digits in txt to a uint64_t value.

detaileddescription.para: Caller is responsible for ensuring that txt has content matching:
If the digit sequence's value is out of range, set *outOfRange to true (if outOfRange is not NULL) and return std::numeric_limits<unsigned long>="">::max().
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Returns true if s starts with prefix.

detaileddescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Returns true if s ends with suffix.

detaileddescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Returns true if s contains substring.

detaileddescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Makes all characters in source lowercase, and returns the result.
Makes all characters in source uppercase, and returns the result.
Returns a copy of the source string with only its first character capitalized.

detaileddescription.para: This emulates the behavior of Python's str.capitalize().

briefdescription.para: Locale-independent case folding of [A-Z] for ASCII or UTF-8 encoded source strings.

detaileddescription.para: This can be used for case insensitive matching where one of the strings being compared either known to be ASCII only by specification (like a URI scheme or an explicit token) or where the specification explicitly notes that only [A-Z] will be matched case insensitively.

briefdescription.para: Trims characters (by default, whitespace) from the left.

detaileddescription.para: Characters from the beginning of s are removed until a character not in trimChars is found; the result is returned.

briefdescription.para: Trims characters (by default, whitespace) from the right.

detaileddescription.para: Characters at the end of s are removed until a character not in trimChars is found; the result is returned.

briefdescription.para: Trims characters (by default, whitespace) from the beginning and end of string.

detaileddescription.para: Characters at the beginning and end of s are removed until a character not in trimChars is found; the result is returned.

briefdescription.para: Returns the common prefix of the input strings, if any.

detaileddescription.para: Copies of the input strings are compared. Returns a new string which is the longest prefix common to both input strings. If the strings have no common prefix, an empty string is returned.

briefdescription.para: Returns the suffix of a string.

detaileddescription.para: Returns characters after the final character delimiter (default ".") of a string. Thus suffix of "abc.def" is "def" using "." as the delimiter. If the delimiter does not occur, the empty string is returned.

briefdescription.para: Returns everything up to the suffix of a string.

detaileddescription.para: Returns characters before the final character delimiter (default ".") of a string. Thus not-suffix of "abc.def" is "abc" using "." as the delimiter. If the delimiter does not occur, the original string is returned.

briefdescription.para: Returns the base name of a file (final component of the path).
Returns the path component of a file (complement of TfGetBaseName()).

detaileddescription.para: The returned string ends in a '/' (or possibly a '\' on Windows), unless none was found in fileName, in which case the empty string is returned. In particular, TfGetPathName(s)+TfGetBaseName(s) == s for any string s (as long as s doesn't end with multiple adjacent slashes, which is illegal).

briefdescription.para: Replaces all occurrences of string from with to in source.

detaileddescription.para: Returns a new string which is created by copying source and replacing every occurrence of from with to. Correctly handles the case in which to contains from.

briefdescription.para: Concatenates the strings (begin, end), with default separator.

detaileddescription.para: Returns the concatenation of the strings in the range begin to end, with separator (by default, a space) added between each successive pair of strings.

briefdescription.para: Concatenates strings, with default separator.

detaileddescription.para: Returns the concatenation of the strings in strings, with separator (by default, a space) added between each successive pair of strings.

briefdescription.para: Concatenates strings, with default separator.

detaileddescription.para: Returns the concatenation of the strings in strings, with separator (by default, a space) added between each successive pair of strings.

briefdescription.para: Breaks the given string apart, returning a vector of strings.

detaileddescription.para: The string source is broken apart into individual words, where a word is delimited by the string separator. This function behaves like pythons string split method.

briefdescription.para: Breaks the given string apart, returning a vector of strings.

detaileddescription.para: The string source is broken apart into individual words, where a word is delimited by the characters in delimiters. Delimiters default to white space (space, tab, and newline).
No empty strings are returned: delimiters at the start or end are ignored, consecutive delimiters are treated as though they were one, and an empty input will result in an empty return vector.

briefdescription.para: Breaks the given string apart, returning a set of strings.

detaileddescription.para: Same as TfStringTokenize, except this one returns a set.

briefdescription.para: Breaks the given quoted string apart, returning a vector of strings.

detaileddescription.para: The string source is broken apart into individual words, where a word is delimited by the characters in delimiters. This function is similar to TfStringTokenize, except it considers a quoted string as a single word. The function will preserve quotes that are nested within other quotes or are preceded by a backslash character. errors, if provided, contains any error messages. Delimiters default to white space (space, tab, and newline).

memberdef.argsstring: (const std::string &source, char openDelimiter, char closeDelimiter, char escapeCharacter='\0', std::string *errors=NULL)
memberdef.name: TfMatchedStringTokenize

briefdescription.para: Breaks the given string apart by matching delimiters.

detaileddescription.para: The string source is broken apart into individual words, where a word begins with openDelimiter and ends with a matching closeDelimiter. Any delimiters within the matching delimiters become part of the word, and anything outside matching delimiters gets dropped. For example, TfMatchedStringTokenize("{a} string {to {be} split}", '{', '}') would return a vector containing "a" and "to {be} split". If openDelimiter and closeDelimiter cannot be the same. errors, if provided, contains any error messages.

memberdef.argsstring: (const std::string &source, char openDelimiter, char closeDelimiter, std::string *errors)
memberdef.name: TfMatchedStringTokenize

briefdescription.para: This overloaded version of TfMatchedStringTokenize does not take an escapeCharacter parameter but does take.

detaileddescription.para:
errors.
It allows TfMatchedStringTokenize to be called with or without an escapeCharacter and with or without errors.
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

briefdescription.para: Convert an arbitrary type into a string.

detaileddescription.para: Use the type's stream output operator to convert it into a string. You are free to use the stream operators in ostreamMethods.h, but are not required to do so.
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

memberdef.argsstring: (double d, char *buffer, int len, bool emitTrailingZero)
memberdef.name: TfDoubleToString

briefdescription.para: Writes the string representation of d to buffer of length len.

detaileddescription.para: If emitTrailingZero is true, the string representation will end with .0 in the case where d is an integer otherwise it will be omitted. The buffer length must be at least 25 in order to ensure that all doubles values can be represented. Returns whether the conversion was successful.

briefdescription.para: Convert a string to an arbitrary type.

detaileddescription.para: Use the type's stream input operator to get it from a string. If status is non-NULL and instring cannot be converted to a T, *status is set to false; otherwise, *status is not modified.

briefdescription.para: Convert a string to an arbitrary type.

detaileddescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.
Use the type's stream input operator to get it from a string. If status is non-NULL and instring cannot be converted to a T, *status is set to false; otherwise, *status is not modified.

briefdescription.para: Returns a string with glob characters converted to their regular expression equivalents.

detaileddescription.para: Currently, this transforms strings by replacing all instances of '.' with '.', '*' with '.*', and '?' with '.', in that order.

briefdescription.para: Process escape sequences in ANSI C string constants.

detaileddescription.para: The following escape sequences are accepted:

\\: backslash
\a: ring the bell
\b: backspace
\f: form feed
\n: new line
\r: carriage return
\t: tab
\v: vertical tab
\xdd: hex constant
\ddd: octal constant
So, if the two-character sequence "\\n" appears in the string, it is replaced by an actual newline. Each hex and octal constant translates into one character in the output string. Hex constants can be up to 2 digits, octal constants can be up to 3 digits. Both are terminated by a character that is not a valid constant. Note that it is good practice to encode hex and octal constants with maximum width (2 and 3 digits, respectively) using leading zeroes if necessary. This avoids problems where characters after the hex/octal constant that shouldn't be part of the constant get interpreted as part of it. For example, the sequence "\x2defaced" will produce the characters "-efaced" when what was probably intended was the character 0x02 (STX) followed by "defaced". Illegal escape sequences are replaced by the character following the backslash, so the two character sequence "\\c" would become "c". Processing continues until the input hits a NUL character in the input string - anything appearing after the NUL will be ignored.

briefdescription.para: Concatenate two strings containing '/' and '..' tokens like a file path or scope name.

detaileddescription.para: Tokenize the input strings using a '/' delimiter. Look for '..' tokens in the suffix and construct the appropriate result.
Examples:

briefdescription.para: Test whether identifier is valid.

detaileddescription.para: An identifier is valid if it follows the C/Python identifier convention; that is, it must be at least one character long, must start with a letter or underscore, and must contain only letters, underscores, and numerals.

briefdescription.para: Produce a valid identifier (see TfIsValidIdentifier) from in by replacing invalid characters with '_'.

detaileddescription.para: If in is empty, return "_".

briefdescription.para: Escapes characters in in so that they are valid XML.

detaileddescription.para: Returns the name with special characters (&, <, >, ", ') replaced with the corresponding escape sequences.

briefdescription.para: Functions/classes for string manipulation.
